Description: Apple Inc. conducts a 2-for-1 stock split, doubling the number of shares outstanding.
Verizon Communications completes acquisition of MCI (formerly WorldCom) for approximately $7.6 billion.
Chinese stock market experiences significant rally with Shanghai Composite index reaching new highs.
Commercial real estate prices reach peak levels before subsequent decline begins.
Federal Reserve maintains federal funds rate at 5.25%, the peak of the tightening cycle.
U.S. house prices decline for first time in 11 years on annual basis, median prices fall 1.7%.
Dow Jones Industrial Average falls 416 points (3.3%), its biggest one-day point loss since 9/11.
More than 25 subprime mortgage lending firms declare bankruptcy in February and March 2007.
New Century Financial Corporation, largest U.S. subprime lender, files for bankruptcy protection.
The Blackstone Group completes IPO raising $4.13 billion, becoming a publicly traded company.
Bear Stearns announces that two of its hedge funds have lost nearly all investor capital.
Bear Stearns High-Grade Structured Credit Fund and High-Grade Structured Credit Strategies Fund are liquidated.
American Home Mortgage Investment Corporation files for bankruptcy amid subprime mortgage crisis.
BNP Paribas suspends withdrawals from three hedge funds citing 'complete evaporation of liquidity.'
Federal Reserve lowers discount rate by 0.5% to provide liquidity to financial markets.
Northern Rock, British bank, seeks emergency support from Bank of England; depositor panic ensues.
Federal Open Market Committee cuts federal funds rate from 5.25% to 4.75%.
NetBank files for bankruptcy due to exposure to subprime home loans.
Dow Jones Industrial Average hits record closing price of 14,164.53.
Citigroup, Bank of America, and JPMorgan Chase announce $80 billion Master Liquidity Enhancement Conduit.
U.S. stock markets enter correction territory as financial sector concerns mount.
Federal Reserve institutes Term Auction Facility to supply short-term credit to banks.
U.S. economy officially enters recession; unemployment reaches 5%.
FTSE 100 Index plunges 5.5% (323.5 points), largest crash since 9/11 attacks.
Federal Reserve cuts interest rates by 0.75% (75 basis points), largest cut in 25 years.
Merrill Lynch announces $7.9 billion in write-downs on mortgage-backed securities.
Carlyle Capital Corporation receives default notice after failing margin calls.
Federal Reserve cuts federal funds rate from 3.5% to 3.0%.
Bear Stearns announces severe liquidity problems requiring emergency funding.
JPMorgan Chase announces acquisition of Bear Stearns with $30 billion Fed financing.
JPMorgan Chase increases offer price for Bear Stearns from $2 to $10 per share.
Crude oil prices surge past $130 per barrel amid supply concerns.
Bank of America completes acquisition of Countrywide Financial for $4.1 billion.
Office of Thrift Supervision closes IndyMac Bank, F.S.B., fourth-largest bank failure in U.S. history.
President Bush signs Housing and Economic Recovery Act authorizing FHFA creation.
Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac stock prices fall sharply amid default concerns.
Federal Housing Finance Agency places Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac in government conservatorship.
Office of Thrift Supervision issues public enforcement action against Washington Mutual.
Merrill Lynch agrees to sale to Bank of America for $50 billion (stock deal).
Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection ($600 billion).
Dow Jones Industrial Average falls 504.48 points (4.42%), worst decline in seven years.
Federal Reserve authorizes $85 billion emergency loan to American International Group (AIG).
Investors withdraw $144 billion from money market funds, equivalent to bank run.
SEC announces temporary emergency ban on short selling in financial sector stocks.
Treasury Secretary Paulson and Fed Chair Bernanke warn Congress of potential financial collapse.
Federal Reserve approves Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley as bank holding companies.
MUFG Bank acquires 20% stake in Morgan Stanley.
Berkshire Hathaway invests $5 billion in Goldman Sachs.
Office of Thrift Supervision seizes Washington Mutual Bank (largest bank failure in U.S. history).
JPMorgan Chase acquires Washington Mutual for $1.9 billion.
U.S. House of Representatives rejects $700 billion bank bailout bill initially.
President Bush signs Emergency Economic Stabilization Act (TARP).
DJIA falls 18.2% in worst weekly decline on both points and percentage basis.
Wells Fargo completes acquisition of Wachovia Corporation.
Nine large financial institutions receive $125 billion in capital from TARP.
PNC Financial Services acquires National City Corporation for $5.4 billion.
Stock markets worldwide fall 10% or more amid financial crisis panic.
Federal Reserve and Treasury announce restructuring of government financial support for AIG.
U.S. Treasury announces HOPE NOW alliance loan modification program.
Ford, GM, and Chrysler executives testify before Congress requesting TARP access.
Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac suspend mortgage foreclosures until January 2009.
Treasury Department, Federal Reserve, and FDIC announce Citigroup rescue package.
Federal Reserve approves Bank of America's acquisition of Merrill Lynch.
SEC approves measures for increased transparency at credit rating agencies.
National Bureau of Economic Research announces U.S. recession began in December 2007.
Treasury Department authorizes loans for General Motors ($13.4 billion) and Chrysler ($4 billion).
Federal Reserve approves CIT Group application to become bank holding company.
Global economies begin formal recession declarations; central banks cut rates in coordination.
Dow Jones falls to 7,949.09, its lowest level since September 2003.
DJIA closes at lowest value since 1997; U.S. government increases Citigroup stake to 36%.
Stock price declines compared to those of the Great Depression era.
S&P 500 reaches lowest point at 676.53 (approximate bottom of crisis).
Federal Reserve cuts federal funds rate to near-zero (0-0.25% range).
Federal Reserve releases results of stress tests for major financial institutions.
General Motors emerges from Chapter 11 bankruptcy after government restructuring.
Chrysler emerges from Chapter 11 bankruptcy with Fiat partnership.
AIG announces $3 billion profit in third quarter as markets stabilize.
President Obama proposes comprehensive financial system reform package.
Results of supervisory capital assessment program (stress tests) released publicly.
S&P 500 crosses 1,000 level as investor sentiment improves.
Stock indices approach pre-crisis levels; credit markets show signs of normalization.
Federal Reserve indicates interest rates likely to remain near zero for extended period.
Stock markets continue recovery with S&P 500 advancing further.
Dow Jones Industrial Average breaks 10,000 barrier for first time since 2008.
Deepwater Horizon oil rig explosion causes largest environmental disaster.
Dow Jones suffers worst intra-day point loss of 998.5 points (9%), then partially recovers.
S&P 500, Nasdaq experience rapid declines and rebounds; individual stocks fall to pennies.
Procter & Gamble stock drops 37% before recovering; prices momentarily reach $100,000+.
Greek debt crisis fears spread; European leaders announce â‚¬110 billion bailout package for Greece.
SEC approves broader circuit breaker rules for index securities and individual stocks.
U.S. unemployment rate holds above 9% as recovery remains uneven.
SEC brings civil fraud charges against Goldman Sachs for mortgage CDO misrepresentation.
President Obama signs Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform Act into law.
National Bureau of Economic Research declares recession ended in June 2009.
Continuing benefits of American Recovery Act visible in job growth and GDP expansion.
